JUDGES: Françoise Tulkens;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Kristina Pardalos;Nona Tsotsoria;Vladimiro Zagrebelsky
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE , in the context of an operation carried out against the illegal armed organisation ORG ( “ Party of God ” ) , the applicant was arrested and taken into police custody .

CARDINAL . The applicant signed a “ form explaining the rights of arrested persons ” and was notified of the charges against him . He was informed of his right to remain silent and to see a lawyer at the end of the police custody period . The police questioned him . The applicant exercised his right to remain silent .

CARDINAL . A search was carried out at the applicant ’s home . The police seized an audio - cassette . The transcript of the tape was worded as follows : “ The tape is , for the most part , inaudible . There are incomprehensible speeches in NORP . It also contains songs , in which the word ‘ sharia’ can be heard , but the sentences are also incomprehensible . ”
CARDINAL . Throughout this period , the applicant continued to remain silent .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was placed in pre - trial detention by a judge of ORG .

CARDINAL . In an indictment dated DATE , the applicant and CARDINAL other persons were charged with being members of ORG by the public prosecutor at ORG . The latter called for the applicant ’s conviction on the basis of LAW .

CARDINAL . The first hearing took place on DATE before ORG ( “ the State Security Court ” ) . The applicant , assisted by his lawyer , denied all the charges against him . He claimed that the audio - cassette seized from his home belonged to his mother and that he did not know what was on it .

CARDINAL . At the hearing on DATE the judges read out statements by CARDINAL other persons charged in separate criminal proceedings concerning the same organisation , which named the applicant as one of the leading members of the organisation . The accused were also shown seized documents pertaining to the organisation . Counsel for the applicant addressed the court and argued that the elements constituting the offence had not been made out . He claimed that the applicant should be tried for aiding and abetting an illegal organisation on the basis of LAW , and not for belonging to such an organisation . He did not ask to call any witnesses .
CARDINAL . During the hearings of DATE , DATE and DATE the applicant ’s lawyer repeated his previous submissions and requested that his client benefit from the provisions of LAW ( Law no . DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant argued his case at the hearing of DATE . He claimed to have no ties with the organisation in question and asked to be acquitted . His lawyer also addressed the court and referred once again to the defence pleadings that he had filed during the trial , requesting , under PERSON no . DATE , a stay of the proceedings brought against his client .
CARDINAL . At the end of the hearing , ORG sentenced the applicant to DATE and QUANTITY months’ imprisonment on the basis of LAW .

CARDINAL . In support of its decision , the court took into account all the reports and documents in the case file . In particular , it gave consideration to the statements naming the applicant as one of the leading members of the organisation . It also based its decision on a document which showed the applicant ’s position within the organisation . The court found it established , among other things , that the applicant was an active member of the organisation .
CARDINAL . The applicant ’s lawyer lodged an appeal on points of law against the judgment of DATE on behalf of his client .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG at ORG submitted his opinion on the merits of the appeal . This opinion was not sent to either the applicant or his lawyer .
CARDINAL . Following a hearing on DATE , ORG upheld all the provisions of the impugned judgment . Its judgment was delivered on DATE with neither the applicant nor his lawyer present .
CARDINAL . On DATE the full text of ORG judgment was added to the case file kept at the registry of ORG and was thus made available to the parties .

CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of NORP law can be found in , among other judgments , PERSON v. GPE ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE ) and PERSON v. GPE ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , § DATE , ORG PERSON ) .
